title: Anet-A6 Octopi LCD backcover with camera

description.text:
This is a backcover for the LCD Screen on the Anet A6 with integrated Raspberry Pi Zero W and RPi Camera 1.3.
I use this for Running OctoPi on the Raspberry.
19.01.2018: Added a version with just 3mm holes instead of the M3 nut inserts.

You will need:
• RaspberryPi Zero W
• RPi Camera 1.3 (I got mine from aliexpress.com)
• Camera Cable Zero to RPi Camera 1.3 (This is a special cable to use the small Camera input of the RPi Zero like this one: https://goo.gl/8MQoxh)
•The screws that are already used to hold the LCD
•2-4 M2 screws to hold the Raspberry
•2 M1? screws to hold the Camera. I used glue, but there are holes, if you want to use them.

How to get Octopi running on your Raspberry Pi Zero W: http://octoprint.org/download/

You can either use the USB ports to power and connect to the printer or the pinout of the RPi. You can find a tutorial how to use the UART connection to the Anet A6 here: https://goo.gl/kmkc7Z.
If you use the USB ports, note that you will lose some of your print volume.

Printer:

Anet A6

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Supports aren't needed but if you like the USB outputs to come out a little better you can use them. Keep in mind that you have to remove them from the camera housing if you use Cura.

I printed mine with a resolution of 0.4 and a 0.8 Nozzle, but you can achieve much better results with a 0.4 Nozzle and higher resolution.

title: Ultra-slim Raspberry Pi Zero W case and GoPro-style Pi Mount

description.text:
Included here are Raspberry Pi Zero W case front and back, as well as GoPro style mounting arm with snap-fit brackets to securely hold the Pi Zero W case. Pictured in the first photo, are also a Raspberry Pi Zero W camera swivel mount, found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504951 and GoPro Mount arms & base found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194278

The Pi Zero W case is based upon a very slick Pi Zero (rev 1.1 I think) case where the Pi Zero W has the same board form factor, but has a somewhat different component layout which matters here because the case is so thin, and has a cutout meant to make it possible to utilize a heatsink on the IC, which was repositioned on the Zero W, along with some components that were vertically taller on the newer board.

The mounting arm is based upon an arm from the excellent Modular GoPro-style mounting system, with tabs added to accommodate the Pi Zero W case.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You'll want to rotate the pieces to put the outer face of each case half against the print bed, and lay the mounting arm so the long edge is down, and Pi case tabs up.

Seat the Pi Zero W in the back half of the case. Press-fit the front of the case, first at top, then bottom, until it clicks into place. If you're using the GoPro-style mounting bracket, press the assembled case against the arm, between the mounting tabs, applying medium pressure at top and bottom of the pi, until it clicks into place.

It's recommended that you install a Pi heatsink, only after you've installed the Pi in the case, in order to assure proper alignment.

title: iPod Nano 7G Case with Clip (/w Zip Ties)

description.text:
We had an iPod shuffle with integrated clip and upon upgrade to nano 7g, we sorely missed the clip.

I tried designing an easy printable one but ended up separating case and clip, so both can be printed without supports. Also, both could be used with a different case / device or clip design.

The cutouts are designed for zip ties that are 2.5mm wide and have a head size of 5x5x4mm (wxlxh). These then sit flush in the top of the clip. I added some double side adhesive tape, but that may not be necessary.

ABS or PETG recommended, PLA might break when inserting the iPod.

Please share your mileage.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you can, print the ipod case with a large layer height (0.2 or 0.25) from 0-2mm, then print with 0.1mm to have nice rounded corners and added rigidity.

I printed mine with ABS and had to scale the model to 101% because of shrinking. Non-shrinking materials might be just perfect, but PLA might crack when inserting the iPod.

title: Prusa Z axis, so many problems yet one simpe solution, simplified !

description.text:
Foreword: This worked so well, I went one step further and got rid of the left smooth rod too: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594693

WARNING: As expected, a POS who has nothing worth to show published a poor imitation of this design. He just modified it to include a regular brass TR8 nut. To thread it to TR8 specs was of course beyond him. The poor thing didn't realize it is even simpler to just remove the smooth rod and linear bearing of the normal carriage.
Obviously, I already tried both and found them unsatisfactory. Otherwise I would have published it.
The thing is a bit more subtle than that. It is why I do not currently show the details. The devil is in the details ! :)
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

One of the Z axis linear bearings died. It was OK when grinding the original SS rod supplied by Geetech (RATS !) but didn't survive the ride on the correct hardened steel rod. All my other bearings have already been replaced by my own made with Igus filament. Out of the question to buy one of these crappy linear bearing.
Why use two guides anyway, the leadscrews are straight enough, one could be used as a guide. And here it is.

It is a modification of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830451 and refer to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2068309 for the genesis of this design.

Ream the 8mm holes for a perfect fit, then finish the top and bottom slots with a thin saw. I did it that way to get a better and stronger part. (The monkey mentioned above missed that too !)
.
Note: I don't currently show how the nut is made (with Igus filament). I managed to overcome the friction issues encountered when trying to just use leadscrews (system was overconstrained BTW). Anyway, the TR8 are too flexible. One smooth rod must be kept.
The mod works really great but needs to be checked in the long run. Then I will redo the other nut and linear bearing or try with TR10. No point publishing something that is not fully satisfactory. Just that I have many things to do.

comments.text: Pretty sure your missing a key component to the design bud.
comments.author: Hammerdan8617

comments.text:
I stated it in the description. I just published to show it is possible to use a proper leadscrew as guide at the same time. Of course a regular nut can't work as it will overconstrain the set up. So far, so good but I have to redesign the left side to increase the rigidity.
In fact I test the system for an other machine.

description.text:
This Universal Spool Holder will work, set on a table, for any printer but is really designed to be hung on a Prusa i3 MK2.

As all Original Prusa i3 owners know, the spool holder that comes with the printer is pretty rubbish. There are many alternatives available here on Thingiverse but none of them would handle all of my needs. This spool holder will:

  • Support large (over 2Kg) spools
  • Allow a heavy spool to roll freely
  • Fit any size (width) spool
  • Handle two (or more) spools for quick colour change mid print
  • Hold loose "sample size" coils of filament

The left support has left-hand threads and the right support has a right-hand threads. This allows you to screw both ends together at once (obviously, one end of the rod has a left hand thread). Near the ends of the rods there are small flat sections so you can use a 6mm wrench to tighten the rods. As the rods are printed flat, the threads may be less than perfect. I've included a left-hand threaded nut that you can use as a die to clean up the thread if necessary. I assume you've got a normal metal M8 nut laying about for the other end.

I've included two rod lengths; the 235mm rod is the longest that fits on a Prusa, the 165mm rod will be a little stiffer and is long enough for two standard 750g spools. You will need to print two of whichever length you choose. I've also included an optional left support with a right-hand thread in case you prefer to use a metal M8 threaded rod rather than printing plastic ones.

The bearing holders are designed to fit #608 (8 x 22 x 7mm) skateboard / fidget spinner bearings. You can buy a pack of ten on eBay for less than £3.00. In truth, roller bearings are overkill for this application so I've include optional bearing replacement disks to use instead. You will need to print 4 bearing holders (and, optionally, bearing replacements), 8 if you want to be able to hold two spools at once.

The support legs have a hole wide enough to pass a USB plug for cable management.

If you are planning on using this on a table, you may want to print a third rod for the back feet to add a little rigidity to the unit.

The supports and bearings are up high enough that they won't interfere with the extruder even when Z = 200mm (see photo).

There is an optional loose filament hanger that simply clips onto the rods https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2532195.

You may also be interested in my Filament Guide/Oiler https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2532258 (works with any spool holder)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Notes:

The rods are printed flat (with a flattened bottom) so you need low layer height for the rods. The rest can be printed at 0.20 to save time.

I used E3D's MatX (ASA) which is as strong as ABS but without the warpage problems. PETG should work OK too but I don't know about the rods. PLA would be to brittle.

Screwing the first rod into the supports is straightforward. For the second rod each ends screw into the supports simultaneously. If you are facing the printer, hold both supports against the appropriate end of the rod then turn towards you.

This is a PlayStation 3 slim vertical stand I made because the designs I've found online did not satisfy me. It is 100 mm wide, so it can be printed with any machine. The base thickness is 3 mm and it is quite rigid with PLA. The design has been made around the PS3 model CECH-2504B. It embraces the central part of the side of the console, although it is not very tight, because of measuring errors. However, the console is stable on this stand, thanks to its wide base. The "battlement" on the stand side allows the ventilation of the console.

NOTE
If you are using this in conjunction with Tevo Tarantula Single Motor Dual Z Axis by NinjaCookie note that the 375mm lead screws are too short and you will most likely have the x carriage acrylic blocks knocking into the bottom mounts when you try to home axis. 400mm lead screws are just nice (but risky), optimally get 450mm. There is no harm in getting longer lead screws if there is no 450mm option, as they can be extended upwards above your top mounts. I got myself 500mm ones from AliExpress here

comments.text: If I print an object in PLA will I be able to heat it in the microwave or wash it properly? Isn't the PLA chemical and therefore not recommended?
comments.author: 3Dcowboy

comments.text:
I would certainly not recommend microwaving any plastic, let alone one that is so sensitive to heat. To be honest, I can't even recommend that you make this on a machine that is anything but food safe.
For example, producing this on a SLS machine with nylon, or on a ceramic or metals printer would be more ideal. As it stands, if you're okay with the potential risk, use this for milk and cookies. It will also probably stand up to hot beverages if you print enough walls and a high enough infill.

or, print in PLA and never wash enjoy hot tea :)

description.text: This is a remix of the original "Sink Caddy" by Optic Driver. I used TinkerCAD to modify the original model and printed it on my Prusa i3 MK2S with white PLA filament.

TinkerCAD drawing Original "Sink Caddy" by Optic Driver and my remix. Sink Caddy Remix

I imported the original Sink Caddy by Optic Driver into TinkerCAD and modified it. I cut down both sides to make the caddy more narrow. I also cut out the bottom so that it would fit over a wider sink divider. The original was a bit too small for my sink. The remix is smaller and more compact yet still performs the same function without any significant loss of integrity. Thanks for the original Sink Caddy, Optic Driver. It is a very nice model.

Original "Sink Caddy" by Optic Driver Modified "Sink Caddy" "Sink Caddy" remix

comments.text: Awesome! I'm still using mine, May the power of soap compel you my friend :D
comments.author: OpticDriver

comments.text: LOL, thanks. My wife loves the caddy. Our brush was always in the way and leaking on the counter top or something and this was exactly what I had in mind and couldn't believe you had already made one. I did modify it a bit to fit my sink better but your original model was very good. What program did you use to make it. I am new to 3D modeling and learning the basics in TinkerCAD. I just downloaded Fusion360 but I know very little about CAD programs and modeling. TinkerCAD has a lot of very good beginner's tutorials online, so I may just stick with it for now.
comments.author: OpticDriver

comments.text:
I used Solidworks for this, I'm a daily user at my job so is what I'm comfortable with. I actually want to try fusion 360, I believe it now integrates with Eagle PCB/Schematic software. Which is something I find myself using more and more these days.
Ive heard good things about TinkerCad, nice open source software. I think the best thing you can do is to just jump in like you have, do some tutorials and keep learning. Enjoy :D

remixed_from.title: Ultra-slim Raspberry Pi Zero W case and GoPro-style Pi Mount

title: Raspberry Pi / Pi Zero W GoPro-style Camera Mount

description.text:
Included here are the camera mount and swivel components, with a GoProStyle mating joint. Pictured in the first photo, are also a Raspberry Pi Zero W ultraSlim mount, found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504847 and GoPro Mount arms & base found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194278

This model is a slight remix of a model found here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/38b99c4a6ea986a38ce072ee/w/75caf2f3a76fdf77faa14ea2/e/c6ac5f945c5a0bb05d541a37

The requirement of screws into the camera case was eliminated, in favor of swivel pins, to be installed after printing. You'll need to print two pins. There are two separate pins files but they're identical. I used an M3 screw (20mm) and nut to fasten the base to the swivel, although if you prefer to use all printed parts, you should be able to use this set of fasteners: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:192259

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

This design requires a little assembly. First, be sure you've secured the camera cable to the Pi camera board, then insert the camera board into the front of the camera case, pressing the back of the case into place until it clicks into place. Slide an M3 nut between the two legs of the GoPro-Mount-style base. It will be held in place by the mount legs. Insert the M3 screw through the swivel bracket, and base, securing it through the M3 nut, screwing in hand tight, then backing off one rotation. Insert the swivel pins into each of left and right holes in the swivel bracket. place the camera case between the pins, such that the pins pop into place in the holes on either side of the camera mount. This might require some outward pressure separating the arms of the swivel bracket to accommodate the camera case, while moving it into position.

Archery tool for mounting feathers.

Also need 6 screw DIN7991 M3x18 or more and a cut of 2.85mm filament to pin the arrow (see pictures).

Very easy to use!!
First you have to insert the arrow in the tool.
Then you put feather into "Fixador de plomes" and glue it.
Once you glued feathers onto arrow remove "Fixador de plomes".
Finally you turn it counter clockwise to remove the arrow from the tool.

description.text:
Imported the original designs into tinkercad, after much slicing, cutting, rearranging, pasting, and joining...you see the result

I recommend a USB to SATA Portable Adapter it can be 2.0 or 3.0 mainly because the choke point for data flow will always be the 100Mb/s transfer thru the network connection

I recommend DietPi as the OS, but Armbian is very very good as well

I plan on using one of the packages in DietPi to setup a personal headless "cloud" server to be able to upload photos remotely to save space on my phone, also could be a NAS or whatever

See my Orange Pi PC NAS case

This is a wheel kit to allow the CupCake MakerBot to build a wheel larger than the standard 100mm x 100mm MakerBot platform allows.  
As you can see in the more assembled image that it is easy to make paper/card wheel hubs with different "faces" on them to alter the look of the wheels ... Christmas, Halloween etc... but the faces can also be cut into thirds/fourths to MakerBot them as part of the wheel building too.
This is another of many entries to the makezine.com/go/makerbot  contest ...
blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/04/makerbot_giveaway.html
I really need a job ... but I can design a custom part if you like on contract.

MakerBot each piece, then lightly sand mating surfaces to fit them together snugly.  You may want to glue the wheel parts together for added strength, but that's probably not necessary.  
If you successfully make these with a 3D printer please send me the build-files and machine type so it can be uploaded here for others to use.

title: Minifig Golf Cart with Turning Wheels

description.text:
This is a Golf Cart, just in case you might need one for Golf-In-Miniature. It also looks a bit like a dune buggy. If you spend your life in the sand traps, there's really no difference. 
I might change it and add a roof, it it gets rainy. It was made so that 2 Lego Minifigs could sit side by side and have the cart be made in the style of the original "Toy Car" by atartanian.
This revolutionary design, encapulates the wheels in the cart, so they are printed at the same time with NO ASSEMBLY NEEDED - genius. Nice work jag, madscifi, and atartanian. I REALLY like your cars.

Print it, use it and enjoy. 
By the way, this is a print that can really take advantage of Marlin Firmware to round out the tires and axles by making them smooooooth.
On a technical note, this really is the same "Toy Car". I added and subtracted NO VERTICES, and I only moved the existing vertices in the X&Y Directions only! (in Blender) If you note, the file size is the exact same size as the original Toy Car - as it should be. No electons, or vertices, were harmed in making this derivative.

comments.text: One side printed well, the other side was incomplete. Sad.

comments.text: As a word of warning, run this through netfabb before using slic3r (0.8.4), an error causes it to only print exactly half of the car.

title: Xbridge fan duct - Kossel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Xbridge is a fan duct for Kossel printers designed specifically for bridging.
The shape of the duct will pressurize the air and direct it just at the tip of the nozzle, right where you need it.
The air tightness of the print is ensured by 0.8mm tick walls.
Custom supports at the very tips will ensure that none of your support material will end up in the duct.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

=>0.2

Notes:

Supports touching buildplate only.
Don't worry about the bottom surface of the model, the walls are designed to be 0.8mm tick so your printer will do (at 0.2 layer height) 4 bottom and top layers and 2 layers on the walls.

author: Manipulability

description.text:
This is a little fix I made for our kitchen lamp, which originally was held in place by double side tape. Due the moister it fell off frequently. That's over now since I got a 3D printer. :D

Requirements:

One flat head screw per side to mount the holder from below to a kitchen cabinet or onto a wall. Once fixed it takes a little force to get the lamp in as the screw head is bulking in a little. However once it is in place it sits rock stable in position.

I probably could have done the mount base thicker, so the screw would not be in the way, but that would have made the thing more massive and would lower the lamp. No one complained about the current fix, so it is fine for me :D

Probably not the best design, but this is my very first project done with FreeCAD in about a hour, while learning its basic functions.

The FreeCAD source file is included so anyone can adapt to different lamp sizes if needed. Probably not the best, but I am still a beginner.

Happy Printing!

description.text:
I took DNeves fantastic design and just made a few changes to suit the screws I had around the house.

Note that due to different manufacturing specifications in the airsoft world, you may have to file the underside of the bottom rail gap a little to fit your desired rifle.

remixed_from.title: Smooth X-axis for Prusa i3 with Leadscrews

description.text:
Did some modifications to the carriage to be used with a Makerbot endstop. This endstop is sold with most ramps kit. I originally used toolsons x axis endstop but I noticed by screw was a bit long and it was hitting the belt. I modified it so the screw is inserted the other way so nothing interferes with the belt. If you look at the picture, you will see the red endstop bracket with the screw being inserted from the back, this is the correct one to use. I know I posted the other pictures, but that was before I made the modification to toolsons endstop.
The base of the carriage was made bigger to allow for the endstops to be triggered. This allows for more types of endstops to be used.

author: Dcdesigns

description.text:
Roommate was struggling with a jug of tea. As caps get lower and lower in profile, there's a lot less to grip, and trickier to open. Put the M3D to work with its awesome Tough Ink (orange heft, specifically, minimal infill, though you could get away with thick and hollow walls).
The larger one was built around a gallon jug of Lipton tea (which is almost the same size as an Ocean Spray bottle's cap).
The smaller one was built around a bottle of Source Perrier (a fairly typical 2-liter bottle cap size).
Between these two, you should be able to cover most plastic bottles with screw-on caps. If it's a little bigger or a little smaller, just turn the horseshoe around and use the long ends like tongs to get a grip.

Just something similar to what Diana wears as a belt in the movie. Needs something to attach it to a belt.

Update.
I designed this for my custom built printer which is heavily based on the X3. However, when I printed one of these spool holders for my genuine X3 it seems the spool maybe too close to the extruder to work properly. I have added a design that offsets the bracket to allow more room. The "simple spooler" is the original design and the "X3 spooler" is the offset version.

A simple but versatile spool holder, fits to extrusion, just insert the arm into the bracket depending on the mounting orientation. It should be a nice tight (hammer) fit, if not then a drop of glue will hold it. Fit to a scrap of wood for a free standing holder, screw it to a near by wall to save desk space, under a shelf etc etc.

remixed_from.author: mfink70
remixed_from.title: Monoprice Select Mini extended bed brackets

title: Remix of MPSM extended bed brackets

description.text:
I remixed the extended brackets so that I could mount my MK2B heated bed to extend the x and y axis dimensions to 210mm X 210 mm.

I extended the overall length of each bracket and added another hole to the other end of the bracket.

I split each bracket into two parts so that I could print it on my MP Select Mini. The back bracket needed to change the print bed size a little bit wider and disable the skits in order to print it.

  • On the back bracket, the nut hole near the tower are too long and caused the hole would hit the moving mechanism whenever I tried to move the bed to the front (and it would limit on how many the y axis could travel). So I cut off most of the length of the nut holding hole on that side on my test model. Then I used super glue to secure the nut to the position and it still work fine today. Then I go back and modify the model to shorten the nut hole near the tower side. Be prepared to use some kind of adhesion to secure the nut on that side.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175mm

Infill:

75%

Notes:

I used PETG to print this at a speed of 20mm/s. I just printed some ABS with 80 degree of bed temp and the bracket seem holding fine and did not see any sign of melting. However, print in ABS is still recommended just need to be careful about the size changed after cooling in ABS (That's why I chose to print it in PETG at first).

author: Kent0712

description.text:
While fixing an old RC boat, the motor and propeller shaft were out of alignment, making it impossible to use a solid coupler without encountering severe vibration. A flexible coupler allowed things to run smoothly, but the motor would no longer line up with the motor mount plate, so a spacer was necessary.

The spacer I made is 11.25mm thick and lines up with the 25mm hole spacing of a 540/550 size RC car/boat motor. Lay it on either flat side to print, and scale the thickness accordingly to suit your needs.
This is the CHI-HA.

title: Arduino Modular Case (front part) - relative humidity

description.text:
This is a front panel that fits the Arduino modular case (thing:2474893) and houses a 0.96“ OLED display and a humidity sensor printed on a Form2 SLA printer.

How it works:

The relative humidity (rh) of the air flow, which can be connected on either of the tubing inlets,
is measured inline by the sensor and the rH value is displayed on the OLED.

This application can be used for a weather station setup or just to measure your indoor room rh.

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Formlabs Form 2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 micrometer

Things needed:

-0.96 OLED display - https://www.seeedstudio.com/Grove-OLED-Display-0.96%26quot%3B-p-781.html
-Honeywell HIH-4030 humidity sensor - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9569
-Arduino UNO
-some soldering and wires

-Code to read the Honeywell 4030 sensor

Assembly:

The OLED display was mounted to the printed prongs and secured with small dots of hot glue at the end.
The rh sensor was glued into the sqaured mold. I used epoxy since you do not want to "grill" the sensor with hot glue.
Then wire the sensor and the display to the Arduino (instructions can be found online) and you are good to go.

author: larosta

description.text:
Vase system for a Papyrus cutting.
I used an IKEA Carafe as a vase. I print PLA.

I wanted to keep some of the roots lenth in clear water for graphic purpose. So I designed this hollow cylinder shape, to give the essential soil to the plant, but retaining it from making muddy water. This design gives the plant all the watering it needs, recreating the Nil fertility conditions, like in Egypt.

EDIT -
With the papyrus it worked so well that I had to plant it in a bigger pot soon after !
I'd like to see if another type of plant would grow that fast.
May require some cleaning of hairy render due to the travel moves between the basket vertical structure.

The cylinder is made of two shells for assembly convenience. The roots pass thought the holes at the bottom. I've jammed some cotton in it, then clay beads, then soil. The basket cap locks the shells together. A circular indentation on the cylinder can welcome a rubber band to add some clamping. The shape of the basket allows the plant base to remain emerged, and gives some shadow to the sprouts.

It is friction fit. It was designed to be customized on the front. e.g, the name on the front. The uploaded .STL and Rhino 5 .3dm files have the name removed.

Mini plateau cocktail conçu pour éviter que les boissons ne se renversent lors de diverses manifestations : colloques, expositions, mariages, anniversaires, etc.
Il peut recevoir : verre, gobelet, canette, etc.
Les convives se servent en boisson (gobelet, verre, canette), choisissent quelques friandises et libèrent la table d'honneur.
Le mini plateau cocktail est tenu d'une main et permet ainsi de saluer les connaissances.
Idéal en plein air, le mini plateau cocktail peut être posé sur une table : le gobelet ne sera renversé ni par le vent ni par les enfants turbulents. Une légère pente vers le centre dirige le liquide vers le milieu pour éviter de souiller la table.
Le mini plateau cocktail peut être personnalisé et recevoir : logos, prénoms, et divers messages publicitaires. Il est possible d'y apposer des inscriptions en brail.
Pratiques et légers les minis plateaux cocktail s’emboîtent par deux "tête bêche" pour former un bloc compact facile à ranger.

description.text:
I have been building up a LEGO-compatible robotics building kit for my kids based heavily on the blocks designed by @MechEngineerMike.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415854

I got my first pass of it put together, and I realized that there wasn't a good way to turn it on and off other than plugging and unplugging the battery pack. So I started with the calibration brick and made it fit a SPDT toggle switch.

This is a 2x4 brick that is a little taller to accommodate a MTS-102 3-Pin SPDT miniature toggle switch. These switches are readily available either on Amazon or Ebay. The switch should be a tight friction fit in the block.

10 x MTS-1023 3-Pin SPDT Toggle - http://a.co/9XteXN0

LEGO®, the LEGO® logo, the Brick, DUPLO®, and MINDSTORMS® are trademarks of the LEGO® Group.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select V1 (modified)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This part prints acceptably with supports off, but the holes that the wires go through need a little clean-up. If you use supports, it also requires a little clean-up to get the supports out. It's a toss-up either way on my printer.

For tips on printing LEGO-compatible blocks, please see the notes from @MechEngineerMike in the original part.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415854

The SPDT switch should snugly slide into the block. Trim one of the outside legs off the toggle, and make sure that missing leg is under the side of the block with the "ON" text.

Solder this into the positive wire, and run the ground wire through the other hole for better wire management.

just a simple box

It's tuning for Zmorph 2.0 and 2.0s printer.
Primary fan mount replacement and second fan mount. Both with changeable nozzles (for different toolheads).
You'll need one fan (SUNON EB40202S2; 40x40x20; 24V), soldering iron and some cable/connector to get 24V from head PCB. Second fan and nozzles are holded by magnets (look at photos for details). I used neodymium magnets 5x5x1.5mm:

  • (2x) primary fan,
  • (4x) secondary fan,
  • (2x) secondary fan mount,
  • (2x) for each nozzle.

"A" and "B" in stl files names are information if it's for primary or secondary fan (some of them are not symmetrical).
"_1", "_2", etc it's more than one variant of nozzle. It's up to you which you will use (it depends on your print and used material).

Print with ABS! (it's really close to hotend so it should handle high temperature)

Mount thone parts means you'll need to take original toolhead mount to pieces. Theoretically it's really hard to damage printer but remember that I don't take any responsibility for situations like this.

title: Universal tripod phone mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yes another tripod phone mount. I have a unorthodox clamp+ballhead setup that need a compact phone holder, so i decide design my own

  • Simple, slim and adjustable.
  • Standard "tripod screw" so can attach in any place
  • Design 100% printable with no bolts or screws need.
  • Strong as possible (few print->stress->brake->re-design cycle)

Public cad file at onshape so you can better remix.

Companion blog post with my journey.

Notes:

Recomended print settings:

  • Wall thickness ~1.8mm to guarantee threads print solid
  • Layer height <= 1.0mm to guarantee smooth walls and less friction
  • Infill density >70% to guarantee strong mechanical structure
  • Print one piece at time to avoid retraction between pieces and get better quality
  • No support need

title: Multi purpose spool holder for Robox 3D printer

description.text:
This is a modded version of my Polymaker spool holder that uses the Reel 2 or Filament 2 locating lock ring pegs on the CEL Robox DM 3D printer.

It is roughly 46mm in diameter and 60mm long, so will cover most larger holed filament reels. There is an M6 screw thread, which when used with a washer will acts as a stop to keep the reel on the holder, and all of this still means you can access the filament eject & pause button on the Robox. The spool holder is offset vertically, to raise the centre slightly to improve the feed into the filament 2 gate, and stop the larger diameter reels hitting the deck.

Hey guys and welcome to my second creation and second item in the entrance plaque collection!

This plaque can be found in the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California. This is the original park envisioned by Walt Disney himself. So far I am really enjoying paying homage to the best theme parks in the world and I have plenty more to come!

I hope you are enjoying these models and please leave feedback or suggestions in the comments!

Until next time,
Jay

remixed_from.title: MakerGear Simplified Extruder Block with Quick Release and Rear Motor Mount

description.text:
Printed this, functions well, if you jigged your MG prusa with their wooden thingy, then you still have 200 in the x direction, and this design adds nearly 30mm in the z direction
currently printing a giant tardis out of abs with it for one friend, then a second thor for my asian friend who goes all heavy breathy/sweaty palms at the mention of something from starcraft 2
This thing makes the motor face in the Y axis, hopefully allowing another 20mm in print height... I have not tried it yet as i ran out of PLA and am learning to use ABS as i print it...  also i made it all smooth etc as an idea for reinforcing because of the way skeinforge does perimeters, plus it's all smooth, anyway time will tell
This is sort of a derivative of some other guys thing, i will edit this when i find the link to his, he had cad files, so i had a peek, figured i could maybe do better and i dropped mine by 5mm in height, plus the xy twist, hope he does not get offended
oh the toggle tensioners, god how awesome are those

Fairly self explanitory?
For those of you who dont have any blobs, or bits that need cleaning off, or holes that dont need to be at least flushed a little or gently retapped, well dammit i'm not that good. for the rest of you, the filament hole is 2mm, so for 1.75, personally i use a dremel to ream it before use, i imagine 3mm filament people could just as easily ream it with a 3.5mm bit.
underneath the thing, in the cavity your hotend plugs into, i have designed a small support material thing that you'll just have to cut, or snap off, my bridges were not making the gap properly, and the lower outlet of that 2mm hole looked like port headlands on a good day

title: Top-Door-Opener Ikea Lack Enclosure made stronger

description.text:
This remix solves the weaknesses of the source.

I have now used this design for 3 months+, opened and closed door about >150 times. Still holds good. Magnets still strong.

Front door for the IKEA Lack enclosure 490mm

My version of the connectors is for a height of 490mm. (Lack's legs raised).
The length of the arms (connectors) is adapted for this IKEA LACK Enclosure design : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2212749
using the option Upper_Legs_Long_490mm.stl

See my make https://www.thingiverse.com/make:384455 in order to know what to print.

Looks like I can remove my original prusa mk2s when the door is open. No need to dismantle the door.

Parts

Walls and front Door using
4 synthetic glass sheets 2.5mm, 4 x 444 x 490 : can cut that from one 1m2 sheet.
or 3 x 444 x 490 for walls + 444 x 488 for front door for a little more margin

Using 2x(4x2) = 16 neodyme magnets : 10 x 5 x 3 mm
Get 20 of these in case you need more strength
http://www.ebay.fr/itm/172223778879

3D printing instructions

can print everything in PLA if you are confident you have a quite strong PLA, screws printed vertical.
See picture print_orientation_table_mount.jpg
PET should be better I think. But might be hard to print the screws and threads.

Assembly

Please notice that the connector_with_hole part is slightly asymetrical. By about 1-2mm, which might help. Try the orientation that best fits for the alignment of the mags to the triangle.

Positionning : look at the pictures they have the measurements in metric system.
Screw first : top of Table Mount parts should be screwed to the legs at 83mm from the roof.
assemble the connectors and the plexi mounts using the screws and washers, just by hand. If necessary, make them play until they rotate fine.

finding the right place for the triangles

left
put 2 mags in a triangle (same polarity orientation) + maintain top magnet with some strong tape (else it will jump out !)
add 2 more mags on front of triangle, maintain with some strong tape.
hold with your hand the triangle at very approx final position
push up the left assembly to the top
throw 2 magnets in it, they will orient correctly, close with some tape.
add 2 more magnets again on the tape.
now, find the position for the triangle that maximizes stability, mark with stylus

right, do the same.

once you are confident with all position, screw and stick.

chipboard wood (aka shitwood) screws to use :
diam 3mm x L20 for the triangles (3 per Triangle, total 6)
diam 4mm x L30 for the mounts (2 per Table Mount, total 4)

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36465 for the front door handle

video of door action
https://youtu.be/pxghWBwZGv4
https://youtu.be/WngNIq5Koo4

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I would recommend thick walls for the mounts. 3 or 4 layers at 0.2mm

With my prusa i3 mk2, i got very good results for the mounts using
PET ICE PET152 Filament, 1.75 mm, 0.75 kg, Cunning Clear (see on amazon) very strong, low temperature (only 210°) and cheap.

Leave enclosure open ;-)

https://www.amazon.fr/ICE-FILAMENTS-ICEFIL1PET152-Filament-Cunning/dp/B017HAHRPG/ref=lp_9048971031_1_14?srs=9048971031&ie=UTF8&qid=1507229544&sr=8-14

title: Print Removal Wedges to keep sharp tools away from your fingers

description.text:
If you’ve been around 3D prints for a while, your fingers probably show battle scars of the most dangerous part of 3D printing: the removal of the print using sharp objects.

We think there is a better way. After you lift a part of the print (with any standard tool), place the first wedge at that location and put aside all sharp tools.

The second wedge fits in the space adjacent to the first wedge, so we can “walk” the wedges around the print.

In our experience, this method is not only faster than the traditional struggle with standard sharp tools, often resulting in close calls of sharp blades gliding close to our fingers, it is also very relaxing. The separating forces of wedges are quite extreme and you can use time to your advantage. We sometimes just leave a few wedges in place and return after a cup of coffee to see the print separate itself from the bed without any further assistance.

You can "walk" wedges around your print with just two wedges, but we prefer to use 4-6 for larger prints.

Print setting: layer 0.1 MM preferred, 0.2 MM is OK, fill at least 40% for structural strength.

Sizes:
S, small, 7 MM width
M, medium, 10 MM width
L, large, 19 MM width
XL, extra large, 28 MM width

See our titanium binary carabiners and free standing hybrid candles at:
http://www.iomaa.com

Enjoy

title: 3D printed articulating LED lamp

description.text:
Runner up winner of Instructables Plastics Contest!
https://www.instructables.com/contest/plastics/

*** Update (26/09/2017): New thing files added:

  • Arms with three different sizes: 100, 140 and 200 mm
  • New arm type: mixed arm design (hole at one end and a stud at the other). With this you can extend the reach of the lamp one arm at a time (rather than needing a pair of arms). This may replace the other two types of arms (male and female).

Did you know you can buy a Anet A8 for only $129.99? Use the coupon code A8KIDA at Gearbest and get it!
http://bit.ly/2kqVOdO

Having good lighting at your desk or at a reading location is essential for your visual comfort and the health of your eyes. Although, it is not always possible to find a lamp of your liking, or that does not occupy much space on your desk, limiting your work area. In project I made a 3D printed articulating lamp, which can be configured according to your needs.

Possibly the final product will be more expensive than ordinary lamps that you will find in stores. But none will be configurable like this, nor will will let you be proud to say that you did it by yourself! If you have a 3D printer or have access to one in your hacker/maker space, this is an interesting and useful project to equip your workshop and practice your 3D printing and modeling skills.
Adapted from Kenneth awesome Articulating, Wall-Mounted, Magnetic Phone Mount design into an articulating wall mounted LED lamp.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2448971

Full instructions at:
https://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Articulating-LED-Lamp

Be careful when working with electricity. Make sure there is no short circuit and just try to connect to the electrical power plug after making sure that all components are properly connected and double insulated. If you don't have enough experience working with electricity, as for others help.
Don't touch any exposed wire or any metal part of the LED lamp after it's energized! Some LED spots have a metal heat sink. Avoid touching that part when the lamp is on!
Once there are exposed wires, it's not recommend to use it places accessible to children or animals. Under no circunstances use it close to wet surfaces!

It's and experimental design, so you might use it with caution.

Printer:

Voolt3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Only the lamp holder part needed supports.

Full instructions at: https://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Articulating-LED-Lamp

http://bit.ly/2fAancq

It's and experimental design, so you might use it with caution!

description.text:
UPDATE 8/30 - Added files and pictures for CTI Signalman, Sentry, Watchman and combined mount for the USB adapter and network adapter

Will upload TrainBrain shortly (currently printing)

UPDATE: 8/29 - Added file and pictures for CTI Switchman

Oh, and yes, you will need to print with supports so the slot the card slips into in the back will have a proper gap.

Hello, this is the 1st of my mounting brackets for CTI-Electronics model train controller cards.

This one is for the Dash-8 Controller. This way you don't have to worry about the screws being perfectly straight when trying to mount the controller upside-down under your train track, and trying to manage the 1/4" spacers.

I am doing a final print on the Switchman, now, and will upload those files shortly. If there's enough interest, I can put a little cooling fan on the Switchman

Watchman is next up in the queue, followed by the rest. I will post the full suite of mounting brackets to this Thingy, rather than do one Thingy for each.

Oh, and for screws, I'm using M3 metric with allen heads

I printed in PLA

Brainwave is a low cost controller for Reprap 3D printers derived from the well known Sanguinololu. The primary design goal was lower cost, achieved by providing only the minimum required components for a single extruder printer. It can be used to drive a cartesian or delta style printer. Features
  • Small footprint: only 60mm x 79mm!
  • 12V power input
  • Micro USB connector
  • All connectors at edge of board, vertical or right-angle connectors will fit.
  • Atmel AT90USB646 microcontroller w/ USB bootloader
  • 1, 2, 16 or 32x microstepping @ up to 800mA
  • Dual Z-axis connectors
  • Optional per channel current attenuation
  • Heated bed support with separate power input (up to 24V @ 15A)
  • Integrated heater/thermistor/stepper connector for E channel
  • Fan control

• Build, buy (from http://metrix.net ) or borrow a Brainwave
  • Install Arduino 1.0.2
  • install the brainwave arduino hardware bundle from github.com/unrepentantgeek/brainwave-arduino into the Arduino hardware directory.
  • Get Marlin. I am maintaining a branch of Marlin that will compile for brainwave at http://github.com/unrepentantgeek/Marlin/tree/brainwave Marlin HEAD has support, but it doesn't always compile cleanly for this board.
    • Hardware configuration Set micro-stepping selector jumpers (D1, D2) per channel. Short both for 32x microstepping. See table on back of board for other configurations. Default: single-step.
    Set stepper current reference voltages. I = V / 2.55. Default: 1V == 400mA. Software configuration Open Arduino, find the Marlin directory and open Marlin.ino. Select 'Brainwave' from the Board menu. Find the Configuration.h file and change DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT to suit your printer (remember, 32x microsteps!) Power on the Brainwave and connect the USB cable
    (note: the brainwave will not power up off USB, you need the 12V supply.) Hold down the PROGRAM button and press RESET, the STATUS led should pulse. Press the Upload button in Arduino. After a reset the brainwave will show up as a CDC ACM serial device (/dev/ttyACM[0..9] on Linux) and be ready to accept commands. Brandon Bowman wrote up an excellent guide for getting the board working under Windows and MacOS: http://fabbersuw.blogspot.com/2012/12/if-your-brainwaves-got-no-brains-or.html Brainwave wiring diagram provided by Brandon Bowman. Known issues
  • It may take a couple of presses of the RESET button to get the firmware to come up after flashing.
  • You may need a thermistor or similar 100k resistance present across the bed and extruder thermistor inputs. Otherwise Marlin may go into a deathloop and you'll never even see a serial device. Even if it doesn't fall on it's face it will only sit and complain about too high temp.
    • Primary development of Brainwave will continue at http://github.com/unrepentantgeek/Brainwave Special thanks Julie Atwood
    Matt Westervelt
    Frederik Hubinette
    Silas Snider
    Johann Rocholl
    JP Sugarbroad
    Austin Appleby
    Richard DeLeon
    Plamena Milusheva
    Mark Ganter
    Brandon Bowman

So, I've been fighting with this skipping issue for a few months now. I've pretty much rebuilt most of the machine, re-tensioned the belts, bed level, re-made end effector, replaced linear bearings, even the host PC. I burned through a full spool of print starts to figure this out.

comments.text: So D1 and D2 are the solder pads? Is conventional wisdom to solder bridge these to set to micro stepping?
comments.author: unrepentantgeek

comments.text: Yes, D1 and D2 configure the microstepping config.  Short both to get 32x.  You should only find a need to drop to 16x if you are trying to get a feedrate that requires greater than 22kHz step rates, but that would be something like 400mm/s.
comments.author: matt_o_70

comments.text: I guess the idea here is that the board should be cheap enough that if you fry a stepper driver, you just replace the entire board?
comments.author: JamesNewton

comments.text: No actually, if you fry a driver your replace just the fried bit.  This is actually way easier than it looks!  You first cut the pins off the dead part with an x-acto type blade, removing the body.  Then you sweep the pins off the board with a hot iron.  Apply lots of flux to the pads and tack the new chip in place at the corners, then solder the rest down.  It helps to have some sort of magnification, but it can be done without.
comments.author: JamesNewton

A mashup of assorted Creative Commons and Open Source clipart, and the Nerdhaus Miniature bases.

This collection contains 9 civilians, 9 infantry, 6 zombies, and 9 assorted animals monsters. They're all silhouettes and can be printed at fairly low resolutions, then inserted into the included miniature bases for some quick and dirty crowds or armies in any tabletop game.

Two variations of the bases are included: a simple version, and a numbered version 1-9 embossed on each base. The latter are handy when large number of enemies are are in play during tabletop combat: "Zombie number four takes damage" is always easier to call out than "The one right next to the door on the left" etc.

Still a work in progress, as a few of the creatures and a few of the minis have thin walls that can be problematic for some printers.

It was originally designed by ©Problem Solvers
The bolt required is T25 or hex bolt that fits on the Matchmaker. Thread size is M5 x 1.0

I bought it and 3d-modeled it by accurately measuring all the dimensions with a digital caliper in millimeters. Some curves were estimated. Angles were measured to the best of my ability

Inspiration from
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1678678
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1322805
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1619362

Those are very good SD cases, but as an underwater and wildlife photographer I needed a rugged and weather resistant case, that can handle a splash into saltwater, heavy rain and dust, snow and so on, so with the inspiration from those stl's I designed a new SD card case with this features:

  • Thicker walls
  • Thicker top and bottoms
  • Grove for a O-Ring seal (fits a 40x3.5mm o-ring seal)
  • Hole in the top for attaching a nylon rope for attaching a carabiner or whatever, so I can attach the case to my body or camera bag.
  • slots for 6 SD cards and 2 Micro SD cards
  • Room in the top for some foam padding

For best ruggedness print the top at 0.1mm resolution and the bottom with either 0.1mm resolution or as a dual process print where the print prints at 0.2mm up to the threading and 0.1mm from the start of the threading and up. Use 50% honeycomb infill for the lower parts of the base and the top, and 100% infill for the threaded parts of the base. To make it rugged it is important to use a suitable type of plastic, I prefer PETG or PC (I alos have had good result printing it in Colorfabb XT-CF20 [Requiers hardened nozzle]). And print with like 6 outline shells, 6 bottom and top layers.

To improve the ruggedness you can do post process where you spray the parts with a plastic filler spray (e.g.. Steel Plastic Spray), let it dry, sand it down with semi fine grit sandpaper (eg.180 grit) and repeat the process 1 or 2 more times, this glues the build lines together and fills any holes or cracks in the shell, and complete it with a spray paint of desired color.

If you print this part with a plastic that shrinks/warps when cooling, or if your printer tolerance is not tuned, the SD/micro SD slots might be to tight, if so do not use the case, rescale it according to your printer and the plastic type you print with. The SD / micro SD cards should be easy to insert and remove from the slot. If the shrinkage is to much the cards can be stuck and in worst case the micro SD can snap in half. The tolerances in this model works fine for me printed with PETG, PC and Colorfabb XT-CF20 on a stock Original Prusa I3 mk2S

description.text:

Also added slots so the bolts can tighten the part onto the smooth rods and fixed some busted geometry.

I suggest you don't use this at all but if you must you might as well use a proper nut on the threaded rod. There is no reason to stop using the smooth rods on your Prusa.

title: Vampire Slag Bag Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had a problem: there wasn't a handy place to put a trash can near my printer, so the little bits of slag - skirts, brims, failed prints - wound up cluttering my desktop and falling to the floor. So I designed a little trash bag holder that hung off the side of my desk, right where I needed it.

Then I had another problem: some of the wispy pieces of filament would stick to my hands or not fall into the bag, and they'd get pulled back onto the print bed. So I designed a "comb" that could snag the slag.

THEN I noticed that the comb looked like teeth, with fangs. So I HAD to add evil eyes and eyebrows. I mean, sometimes you just have to finish what you start.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used PLA, but it should print fine with any filament you have handy.

1. Print the two STLs.

  2. Attach the base to your desktop. I used velcro, because that's how I roll, but E6000 or other adhesive will work. You could screw it in, but I think that's overkill - it really doesn't need to support much weight or torque.

  3. Insert a plastic bag into the base, and fold the opening of the bag over the rim of the base. I used a dog poop bag, but a plastic grocery bag will also work.

  4. Slide the top over the bag and into the base.

  5. If you like, slip a scrap of paper between the top and the bag, to highlight the eyes.
I designed this in TinkerCAD, which was much more frustrating than I expected. Feel free to shame me for not learning Fusion360. Seriously, I need the motivation.

comments.text: That's a great idea! I use a ziplock bag next to the printer for my "fail pail". Time to upgrade to a "Slag Bag"!

description.text:
Hi.
I'm sharing this 45 degree camera mount, to fit a SONY A5000 camera on a TAROT 680pro drone. It weights 92grams, much less than any gimbal.
It was designed in 4 diferents parts to get the best print orientation for each part. I recommend to print as you see the parts on the stl files.
I used 2% upscaling to prevent for ABS thermal shrinking, and 30% infill.
After printed some parts must be glued. I usualy use ABS-Acetone solution as glue because It gives the best strenghth.
The camera must be screwed with a bolt and washer and aditionaly we can put some elastic bands to secure the camera.

I always recommend to put some rope between the camera strap hook and the drone, so if somethig happend with the mount the camera will get hanging from the drone.

I set out to build a 3in FPV quadcopter capable of performance similar to that of my 5in builds, but under the FAA's 250 gram "toy" designation. I built this rig on the bottom plate of this frame and and the all up weight, including a 4S 650mAh Lipo is 211 grams.

Here I've included the parts I designed and printed in SainSmart semi-flexible TPU to make this build work for me robustly. I designed a camera mount to press fit with the common, encased vtx/cam AIO FPV solutions. It's got 10 degrees of camera tilt, I superglued the walls of the cam to the part for extra security. There's also a mount for the Furious FrSky Rx that fits on a 20mm x 20mm flight controller stack. Lastly, there's a battery pad to super glue to the bottom of the frame to make sure the surface that interfaces with the battery is flush.

These designs had flexible filament in mind. PLA, ABS, and other rigid materials will probably not yield very good results without changes. For that reason, I have provided the STEP files so you can throw these parts in your favorite CAD software to make the adjustments you need.

UPDATE: I suffered an ESC desync mid-flight and fell 40ft onto concrete which took the lens off of my camera/vtx. I happened to have a Eachine EF-01 camera/vtx module lying around so I designed a new mount for that module's geometry, it's two parts for easier printing and they are superglued together. I've included both sets of models here. Along with this change I upgraded to Tornado T1 1407 3600KV motors, they are slightly heavier but deliver much greater thrust. This set up now clocks in at 213.9g, well under the 250g FAA limit and achieving great performance in flight.

description.text:
Uncle Grandpa (Tío Grandpa en Hispanoamérica y Tito Yayo en España) es una serie animada de televisión estadounidense creada por Peter Browngardt para Cartoon Network en 2013. La serie se basa en un corto animado creado por Browngardt, del mismo nombre en el programa The Cartoonstitute. Uncle Grandpa es un spin-off de Secret Mountain Fort Awesome. La serie es clasificación TV-PG en Estados Unidos. Es producida por Cartoon Network Studios.

El show es una comedia de aventura con humor absurdo que se basa en gran medida en los gags y latiguillos. El creador Peter Browngardt ha citado en el trabajo a los caricaturistas Don Martin, Gary Larson y Robert Crumb, así como a los animadores de la época dorada como Tex Avery a la hora de desarrollar el estilo de la serie.

Cada episodio es de aproximadamente 11 minutos y se presenta en un formato único, que consiste en una historia principal (que tiene una duración aproximada de siete a nueve minutos), algunos bumpers cortos (normalmente una rápida broma visual) y un corto original que se centra en los personajes secundarios de la serie.

La serie está compuesta de cinco temporadas, desde su estreno el 2 de septiembre de 2013 hasta su finalización el 30 de junio de 2017.

title: Free Save the Planet Board Game

description.text:
Save The Planet Board Game is free and open-source DIY cooperative board game. In the Save the Planet Game you and your family and friends can work together to save the planet to win, while learning how to save the planet in real life. The beginner option is appropriate for children 4 and up and the advanced option is a fun game for teens up to any age. This game is open-source so you are encouraged to build on it - make it better, add more good deeds, make a local deed list and make more advanced derivatives. Have fun! The card box holds the Good Deed Cards and the Pollution Cards. You will want two copies one for each level of play. For all instructions and a printable (2d) game board and cards see Save The Planet Board Game
You can also download and print mini avatars from Thingiverse and dice. Please see the derivative section to see the shown components.

Full instructions for playing the game are here: http://www.appropedia.org/Save_the_planet_board_game To print out the box - simply download the stl and print on your favorite open source 3D printer. For the avatars for the game I recommend using various people and Tux designs already on Thingiverse and included the ones I used in the derivatives..

description.text:
This is a simple, adjustable Z-Endstop triggering mechanism that is designed to either be mounted to the platform that the build plate is mounted to, or to the printer frame. You turn the knob until the Z-Endstop is triggered at the desired height.

What you need:

  • An M4 fastener that is at least 40mm long.
  • Two M4 hex nuts.
  • Super glue.
  • The parts on this thingiverse page.
  • Some means of holding the mechanical endstop. I use this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84211
  • Two M5x10 fasteners.
  • Two M5 post-assembly T-nuts.

Printer:

Vulcanus V1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

~0.3, not important

Infill:

30%<

Notes:

Print the 2020 part so that the cutout for the M4 hex nut is facing up & away from the bed, and print the knob so that the flat side is facing the bed. Any non-flexible material should work for this.

Step 1

Thread the M4 screw through the knob, then tighten one of the M4 hex nuts until it is inside the hexagonal cutout on the knob and you are unable to tighten it anymore. Then superglue the hex nut in place.

Step 2

Superglue the other M4 hex nut into the hexagonal cutout on the 2020 part.

Step 3

Screw the M4 screw and knob into the 2020 mount, then attach the 2020 mount to the desired location.

A Radio Frequency Resonant Cavity Thruster, commonly known as the EmDrive, is a controversial proposed form of propulsion that purports to produce thrust from a resonating electromagnetic field inside a copper lined cavity.

These parts are for a full-size EmDrive that operates at 2.404GHz and mode TE013. Other items needed include EMI shielding copper adhesive foil, RF signal generator/vector network analyser, RF amplifier, various SMA connectors, and brass bolts and nuts.

http://miniradiosolutions.com/54-2/
https://windfreaktech.com/product/rf-signal-generator-and-power-detector/
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01L16U5CY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CVQ3KJO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

For precise tests, a torsional pendulum or thrust balance will also be needed: http://hpepl.ae.gatech.edu/papers/2013_IEPC_Polk.pdf

For more information on the EmDrive please refer to here:
http://emdrive.com/principle.html
http://emdrive.wiki/Main_Page
https://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?topic=42978.0

My YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpv9PrLLkxHxhQ-KtBmRXTQ

Safety:
Microwave amplifiers are radiation-emitting devices which pose a health threat. Therefore, extreme caution and proper procedures are highly encouraged. Amateur experiments are discouraged unless you have gained educated and/or professional advice for safety reasons. In addition, because of the materials used and thermal dissipation concerns, it is not recommended to use amplifiers with more than 30W of output power.

title: Sombra Machine Pistol Remix for Cosplay

description.text:
It's a remix of the awesome job made by carloemil for the Sombra submachine gun to includ LEDs in it. Almost all pieces get remixed for this led version.

You can put two leds on the left side to get the symbols illuminate and one in the barrel. Of course I add some space to put all wires you need and battery holder (in the handle) to make lights come to life. Check the options section to know your possibilities.

The three white LEDs I used need one CR2032 battery to work

The holes allow you to put up to:

  • 1 slide switch on/off (size: 5,5 x 4 x 6 mm / 0,22 "x 0,16"x 0,24 "(L W H) for the two leds on the left
    and
  • 1 mini push-button (size: 6 x 6 mm) for the led in the barrel

EDIT 08/31: file "sombra_front3_b" get a little modification to garranty more solidity
EDIT 09/06: I added two files for the logo on left and right side of the gun. I added pictures from both sides when it's fully done.

Hope this could help someone for future project.
Check my profile for more Sombra's stuff ;)

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.14

Infill:

20

Notes:

This one was printed in PLA

To add lights in my prop I make a very simple circuit with two switches, three LEDs, one CR2032 battery and obviously some wires.

The battery holder "sombra_handle2_b" just slide in the "sombra_handle2_a". Don't sand too much to avoid it from falling when moving.
Mine was polish with a rotary tool and sanding with 600 sandpaper. it's very smooth and don't fall even when I shake the gun so it's gonna work for conv floor and some Sombra moves.

How to fix wires on the battery holder, no solder need to save space On/Off switch and the mini push-button I use as reference for the prop (ref in summ)

My remix give you some choices.

  • First you can add some LEDs in the smg obviously

I print the 3 LEDs x 2 switches version for my cosplay, but I also remix a 2 LEDs x 1 switch version if you don't want light in the barrel.
Print the "sombra_mid3 (trigger)" for the first version or the "sombra_mid3 (trigger V2)" for the second.

  • Second, you can choose to had movement on the "whatever this thing is" on front of the gun

Print the "sombra_front3" if you want the original version without movement.
Print the "sombra_front3_a" and "sombra_front3_b" to get the ingame version with movement. Clip the b part on the a part when it's done

If you don't need any of this option please use the original work of carloemil, he did all the job ;)
